page.title: 07The River Kennet
page.content: Wiltshire's chalk country is often parched in the summertime. When the water has sunk into the chalk which holds it like a sponge, it reaches the greensand and the clay which lie beneath it. The water cannot sink through the clay. Consequently it breaks out of the ground in springs at places where the greensand is exposed, either in the Kennet valley or along the edges of the chalk covering. If you study a map of this area, the villages have clearly grown up around rising springs. The{River Kennet}has water meadows on either side. In the meadows the water table is only just below ground level. The volume of water in the river is increased by springs at Kennett, Lockeridge, and Clatford. In the winter the ground is flooded by the swollen river.
